title: George Henry Bennett
text:
George Henry Bennett (18508 September 1908) was a brewer and a politician.
Bennett was born in <a href="Buckie">Buckie</a>, <a href="Banffshire">Banffshire</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. His family emigrated to Australia in 1855.
He managed the Victoria Sugar Co. and later, with a partner, owned Excelsior Brewery, a porterbrewing business. Excelsior Brewery operated in <a href="Collingwood%2C%20Victoria">Collingwood</a> and <a href="Richmond%2C%20Victoria">Richmond</a>. As larger brewers took over the local market, Excelsior moved to manufacturing aerated waters and cordials at <a href="Richmond%2C%20Victoria">Richmond</a>. He took over sole control of the company from August 1883.
In 1880 Bennett was elected to the <a href="Richmond%2C%20Victoria">Richmond</a> town council and, in turn, was elected <a href="List%20of%20Chairmen%20and%20Mayors%20of%20Richmond">Mayor</a> in 1886. As <a href="Mayor">Mayor</a> he was also elected as the second President of the fledgling <a href="Richmond%20Football%20Club">Richmond Football Club</a>, commencing with the 1887 season. He held this post for the next twenty-two years until his death. During his tenure the club won its first two <a href="Victorian%20Football%20Association">Victorian Football Association</a> premierships and gained admittance to the more powerful <a href="VFL/AFL">Victorian Football League</a>.
A <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> and <a href="Protectionism">protectionist</a>, he was elected to the seat of Richmond in the <a href="Victorian%20Legislative%20Assembly">Victorian Legislative Assembly</a> in 1889 and was then re-elected at the next seven elections.
Bennett died of <a href="pneumonia">pneumonia</a> at his home in <a href="Richmond%2C%20Victoria">Richmond, Victoria</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, on 8 September 1908. He was survived by his wife, Jessie, and two of their three daughters.
His bust stands outside the <a href="Richmond%20Town%20Hall">Richmond Town Hall</a>.
